A guild that aims to help players improve their skills in rhythm games, particularly in maimai. We believe in fostering a supportive community where members can share tips, strategies, and experiences to elevate their gameplay. Whether you

articles.title: Accuracy Guide
articles.excerpt: As someone who's been playing maimai and other rhythm games for a very long time, accuracy for me has become a very important skill to master especially if you're trying to really get good at the g...
articles.content: As someone who's been playing maimai and other rhythm games for a very long time, accuracy for me has become a very important skill to master especially if you're trying to really get good at the game. A couple of things I did back when I was starting to get a hang of the game was adjusting my speed until I found the speed I was comfortable playing at, which in this case for me was 8.25. Do note that everyone has their own preference in speed so no need to worry about it when you feel like you play a tad bit slower than others. Another thing that helped me improve my accuracy was the judgement display I use. The judgement display I currently use is 3-D which means perfect, great, and good notes would show a text displaying "Fast" or "Late" depending if I hit the note a bit early or a bit late (again, it's player preference if you do decide to use this type of judgement display because again, everyone prefers something else from others but I do recommend trying this). Knowing your judgement timing mid game helps you adjust your tempo when playing to ensure a higher score count.

articles.title: Slider Basics
articles.excerpt: Ever since I started to play maimai, I found the slider mechanic to be quite easy. Sliders work on a one beat delay depending on the BPM of the song. A star will appear at the start of the slider a...
articles.content:
Ever since I started to play maimai, I found the slider mechanic to be quite easy. Sliders work on a one beat delay depending on the BPM of the song. A star will appear at the start of the slider and will move to the path of the slider until it reaches the end of it.

Judgements as such is determined by the window of time where the star hits the end of the slider. When you finish the slider too fast, it's called splashing. When you finish a slider too slow, it's just skill issue. Think of it as a timer on when you clear the slider. You can differentiate sliders from regular notes by the star shaped notes indicating the start of a slider.

Usually an indicator for when the star will move is another note at the button where the star was hit or in another button entirely. They may look easy at first, but as you reach the MASTER difficulties, you'll see different patterns such as the iconic ウミユリ(Umiyuri) Pattern.
